DISCUSSION AND FINDINGS  
 
The Merger  is the first time the Board considers  a private investment vehicle  acquiring two New 
Jersey energy  utilities  result ing in private ownership  of the utilities, delisting  of the utilities from 
the NYSE , and the elimination of the utilities’ compliance with SEC r eporting requirements .  
Therefore , at the onset, the Board notes that this Decision and Order is ap plicable solely to the 
facts pertaining to this matter , and is not applicable to, and does not constitute review or approval 
of, any subsequent mergers or corporate restructuring.  
 
The Board may only grant the Joint Petitioners’ request to approve the Merger if the terms of the 
Stipulation satisfy the legal req uirements provided in N.J.S.A. 48:2 -51.1, N.J.A.C. 14: 1-5.14(c) , 
N.J.S.A. 48:3 -7, and N.J.S.A. 48:3 -10.   
 
N.J.S.A. 48:2 -51.1(a) provides, in pertinent part, as follows:  
 
…In considering a request for approval of an acquisition of control, the 
board shall evaluate the impact of the acquisition on competition, on the 
rates of ratepayers affected by the acquisition of control, on the 
employees of the affected public utility or utilities, and on the provision of 
safe and adequate utility service at just and re asonable rates.  The board 
shall accompany its decision on a request for approval of an acquisition 
of control with a written report detailing the basis for its decision, including 
findings of fact and conclusions of law.  
 
The terms of the Stipulation address each of the above statutory requirements:  
   
 Competition :  The terms of the Stipulation confirm that t he change in control will not 
adversely affect competition .  According to the Stipulation, New Jersey and federal 
affiliate standards , including t hose relating to retail access and customer choice , will 
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA-24-198

remain in full force and effect .  ETG and SJG already operate under the umbrella of a 
holding company, SJI, and customers will continue to have a choice to purchase their 
gas through a licensed third -party supplier.  The Stipulation further  provides that ETG 
and SJG will not grant undue p reference to any IIF affiliate, and will not contract for new 
natural gas transportation or a storage project owned in whole or part by an affiliate 
without Board app roval.  ETG and SJG will also publicly post Basic Gas Supply Service 
Minimum Filing Requirements for all affiliate gas supply transactions.  
 
 Customer Rates :  According to the Stipulation, t he Joint Petitioners will provide a $75 
million customer  benefit ; approximately $15 million  will pay outstanding ETG and SJG 
COVID deferrals, and the balance will be applied as direct rate credits structured in two 
(2) annual installments.  Customers will be shielded from any pass -through of acquisition 
premiums, transac tions costs , or goodwill.  In addition, customers will be held harmless 
from any increased cost of debt result ing from the change in control through a cost of 
debt tracking mechanism and rate c redit for any increase in the cost of debt directly 
resulting f rom or through the merger.  
 
 Employees :  The Stipulation provides that there will be no involuntary workforce 
reductions, or decrease in wages, benefits or terms and conditions of employment , for five 
(5) years following the closing , except for positions that become obsolete due to the 
Merger.  For five (5) years, ETG and SJG will submit annual reports to the Board detailing 
the number of employees by position and function, and a description of the t raining and 
reassignment for any employees whose position s the Company deems obsolete or no 
longer required.  SJI will maintain local cor e management teams for five (5) years following 
the closing .  SJI will honor all collective bargaining agreements, and existing ETG and 
SJG pension benefits , so long as IIF ret ains ownership of SJI.  
 
 Provision of Safe and Adequate Service :  The Parties agree, pursuant to the Stipulation, 
that ETG and SJG will continue to provide safe, adequate and reliable service , and fulfill 
all of its obligations under New Jersey law, subject  to the continued jurisdiction of the 
Board.  SJI, ETG and SJG will maintain their headquarters in New Jersey for so long as 
Boardwalk owns SJI.  Additionally, ETG and SJG will maintain their existing call centers, 
field service centers and walk -in payment  centers for at least three (3) years post -
Closing.13  SJI will provide ETG and SJG with the resources necessary to invest in capital 
and infrastructure projects to help ensure that ETG and SJG will continue to provide safe , 
adequate  and proper utility service.  
 
 Charitable and Community Support :  Boardwalk and SJI commit that ETG and SJG each 
will provide at least $500,000 annually for five (5) years post -merger. Projects may 
include charitable, educational, community support and economic development efforts. 
Boardwalk also will co mmit to make, or cause to make,  annual contributions of at least 
$500,000 to NJ SHARES for at least five (5) years post -merger.  None of these dollars 
will be recovered from customers.

Next, t he Board must also determine if the terms of the Stipulation satisfy the requirements of  
N.J.A.C. 14:1 -5.14(c)  which are, in pertinent part, as follows:  
 
The Board shall not approve a merger, consolidation, acquisition and/or 
change in control unless it is satisfied that positive benefits will flow to 
customers and the State of  New Jersey and, at a minimum, that there are 
no adverse impacts on any of the criteria delineated in N.J.S.A. 48:2 -51.1 
 
The terms of the Stipulation  provide  that positive net benefits will occur  because  of Merger.   The 
$75 million dollars provided to eli minate COVID -19 arrearages and to fund a direct rate credit , 
together with the employment commitments that extend five (5) years from the closing of the 
Merger , constitute a net positive benefit for ETG ’s and SJG ’s ratepayers  and for New Jersey  as 
a whole .  Ratepayers will receive approximately $60 million via a bill credit, which is a benefit 
that would not occur but for  the Merger.  SJI agreed to maintain employment at levels specified 
in the Stipulation and committed to maintain core management to ensur e continued maintenance 
of safe, adequate and proper service.  Further, the Stipulation contains various ring fencing and 
other measures including the establishment of a commercial paper program to ensure the 
continuing financial integrity of the utility.    
 
Finally, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 48:3 -7 and N.J.S.A. 48:3 -10, the Board must determine whether 
the public utility or a wholly owned subsidiary thereof, is able to fulfill its pension obligations to 
any of its employees.  According to the Stipulation, the p ension obligations will remain intact.  
The Stipulation provides that SJI will honor all existing ETG and SJG’s pension benefits so long 
as IIF retains ownership of SJI.  This commitment does not preclude IIF or SJI from:  a) making 
future changes to SJG a nd ETG's current defined benefit plan if commercially advantageous 
(including, but not limited to, cost effectiveness, administrative efficiency, etc.) so long as 
pension benefits are materially equivalent ; or b) making future changes negotiated b y SJG and  
ETG as part of their collective bargaining agreement negotiations . 
 
Therefore, a fter careful consideration of the entire docket in this matter including, but not limited 
to, the Joint Petition, the applicable law, the Presiding Commissioner’s Orders, and the 
Stipulation,  the Board HEREBY  FINDS  as follows:  
 
 The Stipulation  satisf ies the legal requirements provided in  N.J.S.A. 48:2 -51.1(a) , and as 
such, the Merger will not adversely affect competition, rates, employees, or the provision 
of safe and adequate service at just and reasonable rates.    
 
 The Stipulation satisfies the legal requirements provided in  N.J.A.C. 14:1 -5.14(c) , and as 
such, the Merger will provide positive benefits to the customers of ETG and SJG, and the 
State of New Jersey.  
 
 The Stipulation satisfies the legal requirements provided in N.J.S.A. 48:3 -7 and N.J.S.A. 
48:3-10, and as such, the Merger will allow all pension o bligations to remain intact.  
 
Accordingly, the Board HEREBY  ADOPTS  the Stipulation in its entirety, and HEREBY  
INCORPORATES  its terms as fully set forth herein , subject to the following conditions:  
 
• This Order is based upon the specific and particular facts of this transaction and shall 
not have precedential value in future transactions that may come before the Board and 
shall not be relied on as such;

• This Order shall not affect or in any way limit the exercise of the authority of the Board, 
or of the State, in any future petition, or in any proceeding with respect to rates, 
franchises, service, financing, accounting, capitalization, depreciation or in any matters 
affecting ETG or SJG ; 
 
• This Order shall not be construed as directly or indirectly fixing for any purpose 
whatsoever any value of tangible or intangible assets now owned or hereafter owned by 
Joint Petitioners ; 
 
• Approval of this Merger  does not  constitute review or approval of any subsequent 
mergers or corporate restructuring ; and 
 
• Consummation of the Merger  must take place no later than April 25, 2023 , unless 
otherwise extended by the Board.  
 
The Board FURTHER  FINDS  that the Stipulation provides a reporting regimen to counter the 
elimination of SEC and certain public  reporting requirements , and to protect the interests of more 
than 700,000 ETG and SJG utility customers.  Consistent therewith , the Board HEREBY  
ORDERS  that during any Board initiated investigation or audit , IIF US 2 shall provide the Board, 
its Staff , and the Board’s auditors, in a manner acceptable to the Board, its Staff, and the Board’s 
auditors, access to the recommendations, opinions and/or advice from any entity, Board, 
Committee, or other party advising IIF US 2 in addition to IIF’s US 2’s books and records, which 
in the Board’s opinion may have had a direct or indirect impact on SJI, SJIU, SJG and/or ETG or 
New Jersey, pursuant to  the Board’s sta tutory and regulatory authority as set forth in  N.J.S.A. 
48:2-12, N.J.S.A. 48:2 -13, N.J.S.A. 48:2 -16 et seq., N.J.S.A. 48:2 -17, N.J.S.A. 48:2 -19, N.J.A.C. 
14:4-4.4, and any other relevant authority . The Board FURTHER  ORDERS  that all  expenses or 
charges incurred  regarding any Board investigation , audit or examination of  books and records 
shall be  paid by SJG, and/or ETG , and all books and records for Boardwalk, SJI, SJIU, SJG and 
ETG shall be kept in the State of New Jersey.  
 
The Boar d FURTHER  ORDERS  that, within 10 days of receiving any federal or state notice of 
intent to initiate an audit or investigation , the Joint Petitioners shall notify the Board, in writing , 
whether the entity or entities that are the subject of the audit or in vestigation comprise : 1) SJG 
and/or ETG gas utilities; 2) IIF US 2 and/or its holdings, or 3) a party with which ETG and/or SJG 
has a material transactional relationship.  The Board FURTHER  ORDERS  that the  Joint 
Petitioners shall provide copies of any documents and/or reports resulting from such audit or 
investigation within 10 days of receiving the report or documents thereof highlighting the findings, 
conclusions and recommendations pursuant to N.J.A.C. 14:4 -4.4 et seq.  
 
The Board HEREBY  RATIFIES  the decisions of Commissioner Holden  rendered during the 
proceedings for the reasons stated in h er Orders.  
 
ETG’s and SJG’ s costs remain subject to audit by the Board.   This Decision and Order shall not 
preclude or prohibit the Board from taking any action s determined to be appropriate as a result of 
any such audit nor shall it preclude the Board from any action flowing from the recent SJG audit 
report.14

PROCEDURAL HISTORY 
 On April 25, 2022, the Joint Petitioners initia ted this proceeding with the filing of a 
Certified Joint Petition (Joint Petition) with the Board seeking approval pursuant to N.J.S.A. 48:2-
51.1 and N.J.A.C. 14:1-5.14(c), of an indirect change of control of ETG and SJG to be effectuated 
by the merger of SJI and Merger Sub (a wholly owned subsidiary of Boardwalk), with SJI the 
surviving entity (the Transaction).  
By Order dated June 8, 2022, the Board reta ined this matter for hearing, designated 
Commissioner Mary-Anna Holden as the presiding officer, and required that motions to intervene 
or participate be filed by July 8, 2022.  Moti ons to Intervene were timely filed by NJLEUC on 
June 28, 2022, and by NJLECET on July 8, 2022.  Motions  to Participate were  timely filed by 
ACE on July 7, 2022, and PSE&G on July 8, 2022.   
Only July 8, 2022, EDF filed a letter seeking a one week extension to further consider if it 
would seek to intervene in this proceeding.  On July 14, 2022, Commissioner Holden denied EDF’s

STIPULATED MATTERS 
 
 Based upon the foregoing, the Signatory Partie s hereto agree and s tipulate as follows: 
A. Standard of Review.  The statutory and regulatory criteria for approval of 
petitions involving acquisitions of control of  a New Jersey public utility, as set forth 
in N.J.S.A. 48:2-51.1 and N.J.A.C.  14:1-5.14(c) and any related statutes and 
regulations, have been satis fied.  More particularly, the agreement and conditions 
set forth herein support findings and conclusions by the Board that: (a) the 
Transaction will not have an adverse impact on competition, on the rates of affected 
ratepayers, on the employees of ETG or SJG, or on the provision of safe and 
adequate utility service at just and reas onable rates; and (b) that consummation of 
the Transaction, consistent with  the conditions set forth in this Stipulation, is in the

 public interest, and will result in positive benefits to customers and the State of New 
Jersey.     In support of the foregoing findings, the Signatory Parties have made the following agreements:  B. Impact on Rates 
1. The Joint Petitioners will provide a financial benefit of $75 million to ETG and SJG customers distributed as follows:  i. Within 30 days of the completion of the Merger, SJG and ETG will collectively write-off 100 percent of the total COVID deferrals outstanding as of such date inclusive of all cost categories, including customer 
arrearages.  These deferrals are curren tly estimated to to tal $6.1 million for 
SJG and $8.8 million for ETG as of November 30, 2022. The costs written-off will not be recovered from custom ers. Write-offs related to these 
arrearages will be designated per spec ific individual customer accounts.  A 
list of the customers who received an account credit as a re sult of the write-
off will be provided to the parties within 30 days of completion of the Merger.    
 
ii. After the closing of the Merger, SJI will cause ETG and SJG to issue rate 
credits  to all customers in an amoun t equal to the difference between $75 
million and the amount of C OVID deferrals written off in accordance with 
Section 1.i. above (the “Credit Amount ”).  The Credit Amount will be split 
into two annual installments and will be structured as credits against the customer’s monthly bills.   The first half of th e Credit Amount will be 
provided within 90 days of the closing of  the Merger.  The final half of the 
Credit Amount  will be provided during the  month of the first anniversary 
of the payment of  the first half of the Credit Amount.  The rate credits will 
be funded by shareholders, not customers, and will be issued on a per customer basis to customers of all rate classes. 
 
2. The parties agree that ETG and SJG will not file another base rate case for new rates effective prior to two (2) years from the effective date of the Board’s Orders 
in the 2022 rate cases for each Company. 
 
3. No recovery in rates will be sought for (i ) any acquisition premiu m associated with 
the Merger or any previous acquisition/merger, (ii) any costs associated with goodwill arising from the Merger or any previous acquisition, or (iii) any 
transaction costs incurred in connection with the Merger. For purposes of this 
commitment, transaction costs are defined as (a) consultant, investment banker, 
legal and regulatory support fees (interna l as well as external), and printing and 
similar expenses in each case paid to a dvance or consummate the Merger, and (b) 
severance, retention or change-in-control payments made to employees of the Joint

Infrastructure Investment Group (“IIG”) in any transaction in which the fees of IIG

may allocate costs from Boardwalk or any other subsidiary or affiliate of IIF to

8. For ratemaking purposes, the Board will reta in jurisdiction over all costs allocated 
to ETG or SJG by affiliates.  Neither ETG nor SJG will challenge the Board’s authority to determine the appropriate affiliate cost allocations reflected in New Jersey utility rates.   
  
9. Any savings realized by ETG and SJG by vi rtue of the Merger will be tracked 
beginning with the merger closing until th e first rate case for each company.  
Savings will be flowed through to utility cu stomers in a future base rate case, net 
of any costs to achieve such savings.

H. Ring-Fencing Commitments. 
 
 In connection with the Merger Agr eement by and among SJI, Boardwalk, and 
Merger Sub, IIF US Holding 2 has formed Boardwalk as a wholly-owned, indirect 
subsidiary and special-purpose  entity to directly hold 100% of the common equity 
in SJI and indirectly hold the common equity  in SJI’s subsidiaries, including SJIU, 
ETG and SJG. As used herein the term ‘aff iliate of IIF’ means any entity of which 
IIF directly or indire ctly (i) owns 10 % or more of the outstanding equity interests or 
(ii) has the power to direct the manageme nt and policies of, in each case, at the 
applicable time. For so long as Boardwalk, SJIU, SJI, IIF US Holding 2 and/or any 
of their successors or assigns directly  or indirectly owns ETG and SJG: 
 
30. Holding Company Existence. Boardwalk will be retained in the ownership chain 
between SJI and IIF. Boardwalk Topco LLC, Boardwalk Parent LLC and Boardwalk will have no operational functi ons other than those related to holding 
the equity interests in SJI.  
 
31. Corporate Separateness. ETG and SJG will each maintain their separateness in 
terms of their respective existence, franchi ses, obligations and privileges, including 
their names and logos.  
32. No Debt/Credit Guarantees. ETG will not provide a guarantee for the payment of 
the debt or credit instruments of Boardwal k, or any other affiliate of IIF, excluding 
ETG and SJIU. SJG will not provide a guarantee for the payment of the debt or credit instruments of Boar dwalk, or any other affiliat e of IIF, excluding SJG and 
SJIU. SJIU will not provide a guarantee for the payment of the debt or credit instruments of Boardwalk, or any other af filiate of IIF, excluding ETG, SJG, and 
SJIU. SJI, Boardwalk, and IIF will not repr esent to the public or  to their creditors 
that SJIU, SJG, or ETG has any liability for the obligations of SJI, Boardwalk, and 
IIF, or any other affiliate of IIF , excluding SJIU, SJG, and ETG. 
 
33. No Pledging of Utility Assets/Stock. Neither Boardwalk nor any other affiliate of

35. Refinancings or Debt Replacements. ETG’s and SJG’s current rates reflect the cost 
of first mortgage bonds and senior not es that contain “c hange-in-control” 
provisions that allow the bond and note invest ors to sell (put) their bonds and notes 
back to the respective issuer  at the face amount of the de bt in connection with the 
Transaction.  The Parties acknowledge that (a) to the extent ETG and/or SJG incurs increased interest expense as a result of  issuing new debt (referred to as the 
“Refinanced Debt”) solely to replace any first mortgage bonds and senior notes that 
are redeemed by ETG and/or SJG as a resu lt of an investor exercising a put in 
connection with the Transaction (referred to as the “CIC Debt”) and (b) such 
increased interest costs are included in the ba se rates set in future base rate cases, 
then ETG and/or SJG, as applicable w ill provide customers with a rate credit 
(referred to as the “CIC Rate Credit”) in  future base rate cases for the remaining 
tenor of the CIC Debt on the following terms and conditions: 
  
(i) Within 30 days of the expiration of the put window in connection with the 
Transaction, the Petitioners wi ll identify all tranches (or po rtions of tranches if less 
than 100% of a tranche is redeemed) of ETG and SJG debt that were redeemed, 
including the interest rate, maturity date, and future principal balance and interest expense (referred to as the “CIC Debt In terest Expense”) by year for the remaining 
tenor of each such tranche.  This in formation will be reflected in a tracking 
spreadsheet to identify the quantum of de bt that will be subject to this provision 
and create the baseline for comparison to the Refinanced Debt terms.  Appendix 1 
is an illustrative tracking spreadsheet that  SJI will maintain and provide in each 
base rate case for so long as  this provision is in  force.  On January 15th of each 
calendar year after the clos ing of the Transaction, ETG  and SJG will provide annual 
reports to BPU Staff and Rate Counsel cont aining the terms of all Refinanced Debt 
outstanding as of December 31st of the preceding calenda r year including interest 
rate, maturity date, and future prin cipal balance and interest expense. 
 
(ii) Commencing with the first ETG a nd SJG base rate cases following the 
closing of the Transaction, ETG or SJG, as applicable, will identify the total annual 
interest expense for the Refinanced Debt fo r the test year period (referred to as the 
“Refinanced Debt Interest Expense”).  The Refinanced Debt Interest Expense will be input into the tracking spreadsheet for comparison to the CIC Debt Interest 
Expense for the test year pe riod.  In the event the Refinanced Debt Interest Expense 
is greater than the CIC Debt Interest E xpense, then a CIC Rate Credit will be 
calculated using the following formula:

alternate options in additi on to traditional supply-side  solutions.  The utilities

ownership of non-gas infrastructure must  receive specific Board approval prior 
to recovery of costs in gas distribution rates.

40544707.2  CUSTOMER SERVICE STANDARDS 
Elizabethtown Gas Company and South Jersey  Gas Company (each a “Company”) will 
provide to Rate Counsel and BPU Staff a quarterly report providi ng the results of  the respective 
Company’s performance in relati on to the following metrics: 
1. Call Center 
(A) Average Speed of Answer (ASA) Measure:  ASA  
Benchmark:  Track and monitor only.  
Frequency:  Measured  monthly, reported quarterly.  
Definition:  Measured in seconds from time when  a customer indicates the desire

Request: 
In its response to DOC IR 37, the Company stated that it [HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET DATA BEGINS ... 
HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET DATA ENDS) 
Response: 
(a)The Company has evaluated forming a holding company structure similar to other utility companies in
Minnesota; however, timing of other regulatory proceedings and various circumstances have resulted
in the Company not formally pursuing filings with the Commission and corporate restructuring to a
holding company structure. Additionally, a holding company structure could potentially allow the
Company to access alternative forms of financing (e.g. mandatory convertible debt, minority sale) that
could help manage the timing of equity issuances and broaden the ALLETE investor base, but it does
not fully mitigate the risk due to the sheer size of the capital needs going forward. The increased cost
and complexity of the alternative financing would further distract from the execution of the strategy.
In addition, the Company has operated in its current form throughout its history, and moving to a

Dear Judge McKenzie:  
 
In reviewing testimony from ea rlier in this proceeding it b ecame apparent that , through a 
formatting error , the public and HCTS versions of M ark Ellis’s direct testimony  had different 
page len gths. While they contained exactly the  same con tent (though the public version is 
redacted in part ), the same information in the two versions  diverged by  as much as two pages 
because of this issue .  
 
In order to correct this before party briefing, CURE is filing a  new version of Mark Ellis ’s direct 
testimony with the li ne and page numbers corre cted to match the existing  filed HCTS version. 
CURE is not including a n errata sheet with any text changes because there are no tex t changes in 
this corr ection  – it is only to assure page and line citations will match . 
 
Also enclosed is a Certificate of Service. All parties have been served  by copy of this filing .

4 I. BACKGROUND AND INTRODUCTION  1 
Q. Please state your name, business address, and position.  2 
A. My name is Mark Ellis. My business address is 8595 Nottingham Place, La Jolla, CA 92037. 3 
I am a self -employed utility finance expert.  4 
Q. Please summarize your education and professional experience.  5 
A. I am a former utility executive now working as an independent consultant and testifying 6 
expert  in finance and economics in utility regulatory proceedings. I have over 30 years of 7 
experience in finance -related roles in the energy industry, including 15 years as the head of 8 
strategy for Sempra, now the 4th largest American utility company. Previously, I worked as a 9 
consultant in McKinsey’s energy practice, in international project development for 10 
ExxonMobil, and in industrial demand -side management for Southern California Edison. I 11 
have an M.S. from MIT’s Technology and Policy Program, where I focused on utility policy 12 
and conducted research in the MIT Energy Lab, and a B.S. in mechanical engineering from 13 
Harvard. Please s ee the attached statement of qualifications , Schedule ME -1, for additional 14 
information about my  background . 15 
Q. Have you previously testified before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission 16 
(Commission  or MPUC )?  17 
A. No. 18 
Q. On whose behalf are you submitting testimony?  19 
A. I am submitting testimony on behalf of CURE.  20

5 Q. What is the purpose of your testimony in this proceeding?  1 
A. The purpose of my testimony  is to contribute constructively to the record in order to assist 2 
the Commission in addressing several issues relevant to its dec ision in this case , the proposed 3 
sale of Minnesota Power (MP), a regulated utility that is part of ALLETE, to Global 4 
Infrastructure Partners (GIP) and the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP).  My 5 
testimony will address the  following issues:  potential harms to the public interest from the 6 
proposed transaction , particularly in relation to cost; overall consistency with the public 7 
interest; and impacts on MP ’s ability to comply with the Carbon -Free Energy Standard 8 
(CES).1 I also discuss some potential regulatory requirements or commitments that could  9 
render the proposed transaction consistent with the public interest.  10 
Q. Please summarize your  findings and  conclusions.  11 
A. My testimony covers three topics I believe merit the Commission’s and the public’s attention 12 
and consideration:  (1) the transaction’s  expected  adverse  impact on residential rate s and 13 
implications for the CES ; (2) how the proposed transaction proves, unequivocally, that MP’s 14 
authorized rate of return (ROR)  is excessive , and that excessive RO Rs are the key motivation 15 
for the transaction and the root cause of the forecast unprecedented rate increases ; and (3) 16 
two proposed systemic solutions to problem of excessive ROEs, which are not unique to MP 17 
or Minnesota.  18

customers . [Section based on highly confidential trade secret information begins   2

I also demonstrate how MP’s authorized RO R, by providing extraordinary returns on 8 
investment  well above the statutorily  mandated cost of capital  (COC), creates perverse 9 
incentives to maximize capital spendin g and is the root cause  of the proposed rate increases.  I 10 
then explain and demonstrate  how these already powerful financial incentives would be 11 
exacerbated under GIP’ s ownership, due to its financial compensation structure  as a private 12 
equity investment fund.  13 
I then propose two solutions  to the  systemic problem of excessive authorized RORs. The first 14 
is standardiz ing and codify ing the process of calculating ROR and assigning responsibility 15 
for that analysis to the Commission . The second is to introduce competition for the provision 16 
of equity directly to MP  (not ALLETE), with capital providers competing on the basis of 17 
lowest offered  return , not highest offered price . These solutions would offer significant 18 
benefits, both immediately in the form of materially lower rates, and over the long term in 19 
mitig ating, and potentially eliminating, the perverse incentive to maximize rate  base at 20 
customer  expense . 21

15 III. EXCESSIVE AUTHORIZED ROE S AND THE TRADITIONAL PRIV ATE 1 
EQUITY COMPENSATION STRUCTURE : A TOXIC COMBINATION  2 
D. The Normative Standard for Setting Authorized ROEs Is Well -Established 3 
and Universally Recognized.  4 
Q. Before you were an independent consultant, you worked for Sempra.  In what business 5 
activities is Sempra engaged?  6 
A. Sempra is probably best known as the parent of San Diego Gas & Electric and Southern 7 
California Gas , its legacy utility businesses. Sempra also owns Oncor  (a Texas electric 8 
distribution utility ) and a portfolio of energy infrastructure assets in Mexico, and i s a leading 9 
developer of LNG export facilities in the US. Depending on the day’s market activity, 10 
Sempra alternates with AEP for the 4th and 5th largest US utility holding compan ies. 11 
Q. You were Sempra’s Chief of Corporate Strategy and Chief Economist.  In those roles, 12 
did you work on transactions like the one under review in this proceeding?  13 
A. Yes. Among my responsibilit ies at Sempra, I developed strategic and valuation frameworks 14 
for the company’s major initiatives – investments  (both greenfield and acquisitions ), 15 
divestments, policy positions  (e.g., on climate change) , and technology  selection.  I was also 16 
responsible for reviewing the financial model and economic case for major investments , and 17 
for the enterprise -wide cost of capital function , a critical input into nearly all forward -looking 18 
financial analyses.  The expertise and insight I developed from that experience are directly 19 
relevant and applicable to the proposed transaction.  20 
Q. Do you have any other experience or expertise relevant to this proceeding?  21 
A. Since leaving Sempra in 2019, I have been working as an expert witness in finance and 22 
economics in ut ility regulatory proceedings on behalf of consumer and environmental 23 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT –   PUC Docket No. E0/15PA -24-198

16 organizations. I am also Senior Fellow  for Utilities at the American Economic Liberties 1 
Project (AELP), an anti -monopoly think tank.  2 
One of my focus areas is utilities’ authorized  rate of return  (ROR) . I recently published a 3 
paper (included with my testimony as Schedule ME -2) for AELP explai ning, to a policy - 4 
maker audience  ROR’s centrality to u tility profitability and decision -making.11 The paper  5 
discusses  the legal principles , grounded in long -standing Supreme Court  precedent , that are 6 
supposed to guide regulators in setting a just a nd reasonable ROR : equal to the market -based 7 
cost of capital , the “ROR=COC standard .” 8 
Q. Which Supreme Court Cases established the ROR=COC standard?  9 
A. The principle that rate of return should be set equal to the cost of capital  dates back to a 10 
concurring opinion penned by Supreme Court Justice Brandeis in 192312 and was formally 11 
adopted by the full Court in its landmark 1944 Hope Natural Gas  decision.13 MP cost of 12 
capital witness Ann Bulkley’s Brattle Group colleague s, Lawrence Kolbe  and James Read , 13 
explain ed the derivation of the ROR=COC standard  from Hope  in their book, The Cost of   14 
 
11 Mark Ellis, Rate of Return Equals Cost  of Capital: A Simple, Fair Formula  to Stop Investor -
Owned Utilities from  Overcharging  the Public , American Economic Liberties Project (Jan. 
2025), https://www.economicliberties.us/wp -content/uploads/2025/01/20250102 -aelp-ror-
v5.pdf . Schedule ME-2.  
12 Southwestern Bell Tel. Co. v. Public Svc. Comm’n, 262 U.S. 276, 291 (1923) (“The 
compensation which the Constitution guarantees an opportunity to earn is the reasonable cost 
of conducting the business. Cost includes, not only operating expenses, but also capital 
charges. Capital charges cover the allowance, by way of interest, for the use of the capital, 
whatever the nature of the security issued therefor, the allowance for risk incurred, and enough 
more to attract capital.”).  
13 FPC v. Hope Nat. Gas Co., 320 U.S. 591 (1944) .

17 Capital: Estimating the Rate of Return for Public Utilitie s – the very title an explicit 1 
endorsement of the standard . They  begin by citing the relevant passage of Hope : 2 
The ratemaking process under the [Natural Gas] Act, i.e., the fixing of “just and 3 
reasonable ” rates, involves a balancing of the investor and the consumer interests. 4 
… From the investor or company point of view, it is  important that there be 5 
enough revenue not only for operating expenses, but also for the capital costs of 6 
the business. These include service on  the debt and dividends on the stock ... By 7 
that standard, the return to the equity owner should be commensurate with returns 8 
on investments in other enterprises having corresponding risk s.14 9 
Kolbe and Read  continue:  10 
Since by definition the cost of capital of a regulated firm represents precisely the 11 
expected return that investors could anticipate from other investments while 12 
bearing no more and no less risk, and since investors will not provide capital 13 
unless the investment  is expected to yield its opportunity cost of capital, the 14 
correspondence of the definition of the cost of capital  with the court’s definition 15 
of legally required earnings appears clear. H ope refers to both “commensurate” 16 
earnings and the attraction of capital. These two approaches are harmonized when 17 
the allowed rate of return is set equal to the cost of capital.15 18 
In short, “the return … commensurate with returns on investments in other enterprises having 19 
corresponding risks” is simply the “opportunity cost of capital .” 20 
Q. Does the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission recognize the ROR=COC standard?  21 
Yes, and so does MP. As Ann E. Bulkley, MP’s cost of capital expert , explains,  citing 22 
Minnesota Stat. § 216B.16, subd. 6,  “In determining just and reasonable rates, the 23 
Commission is required to give due consideration to the utility’s cost of furnishing service  24 
which includ es a fair reasonable return on investment .” She defines a fair and  reasonable 25 
return as one sufficient to attract capital , i.e., the market -based “cost of capital. ” She 26 
 
14 FPC v. Hope Nat. Gas Co., 320 U.S. 591, at 603  (1944) . 
15 A. Lawrence Kolbe, James A. Read Jr., and George R. Hall, The Cost of Capital: Estimating 
the Rate of Return for Public Utilities , p. 21 -25 (MIT Press, 1984).

18 concludes  by equating the “market -required ROE” with the “cost of equity.”16 Consistent 1 
with this principle, in MP’s most recent rate case, Ms. Bulkley describ ed the purpose of her 2 
testimony as “provid[ing] a recommendation regarding the appropriate return on equity ,” 3 
then “estimated [MP’s] cost of equity  by applying several traditional estimation 4 
methodologies”  and equated the two.17 5 
Q. Have other regulatory bodies endorsed the ROR=COC standard?  6 
A. Similarly, MP access to capital witness John D. Quackenbush, in a report for the National 7 
Association of Regulatory Utilit y Commissioners (NARUC ), of which Minnesota is a 8 
member18, summarizes the basis for the ROR=COC standard:  9 
“Fundamental financial concepts demonstrate that the fair rate of return to use in 10 
ratemaking for a utility is its cost of capital in order to achieve the proper balance 11 
between customers and investors .”19 12 
FERC has similarly endorsed the ROR=COC standard:  13 
There is compelling economic justification for relying on the market cost of 14

Finally, while not a regulator, widely -cited utility ROR expert Roger Morin has also endorsed  3

The regulator should set the allowed rate of return equal to the cost of capital so 5 
that the utility can achieve the optimal rate of investment at the minimum price to 6

Basically, equity financing costs are just as subject to the foundational  utility cost -of-service 8 
regulatory model (COSR) as are operational costs , depreciation and amortization , interest, 9 
and taxes . Utilities are entitled to recover only actual, prudently incurred costs. COSR is 10 
“cost -of,” not “cost -plus.” 11

problem.  18

Q. What are the implications of excess authorized ROEs for understanding this 3 
transaction and assessing whether it is in the public interest?  4 
A. Essentially, utilities raise capital at a relatively low cost – i.e., the cost of capital or expected 5 
return22 – in financial markets and invest it in long -lived infrastructure at a significantly 6 
higher return – the authorized rate of return.  We know this  is true because t he foundational 7 
principle of finance  – discounted present value – tells us that an asset ’s value will equal the 8 
cost of the initial investment if and only if its expected rate of return  is equal to  its risk- 9 
adjusted cost of capital.  [Section based on highly confidential trade secret information begins 10

process that can only be called financial alchemy, excess RORs turn every dollar of 13 
shareholder capital invested by a utility operating company into a multiple – currently 14 
approximately 2.2x – in shareholder market capitalization.23 15 
This premium , known as the price - or market -to-book ratio (P/B or M/B, respectively)  16 
reflects the expected future wealth transfer from customers to utility shareholders  arising 17

G. ALLETE’S  Unearned Windfall Is a Regulatory Choice . 7 
Q. So what does the $1.5 billion that GIP/CPP are offering ALLETE  shareholders on top 8 
of their actual investment reflect?  9 
A. ALLETE  shareholders ’ $1.5-billion windfall is purely and only an artifact of MP’s MPUC - 10 
granted p ocket -picking monopoly . They are paying up -front for the future value of the excess 11 
profits , arising from authorized ROEs greater than MP’s market -based COE, that GIP/CPP  12 
expect the Commission  to continue to allow MP to collect . 13 
Q. That’s a strong claim. Please explain.  14 
A. I’m going to use a simplified, but relatively accurate, mathematical description of the basic 15 
utility financial model.  16 
If one were to look at GIP/CPP’s financial model for this transaction, they would quickly 17 
become overwhelmed by its detail , size, and complexity. At root, though, utilit ies have a 18 
simple  business model : profit is a fixed fraction  (the ROE ) of invested capital , which grows 19 
steadily over time . Utility cash flow profile s are predictable and stable  and, therefore , 20 
relatively easy to value . As a result, f inance professionals and economists have  been able to 21 
develop simple mathematical models that accurately capture the  inter-relationships between 22

23 the key economic levers of the utility business  model – ROE, COE,  book equity (i.e., the 1 
equity portion of its rate base) , and growth  – and its market value . 2 
One such model that accurately captures the key value -drivers in this transaction is the  3 
sustainable -growth discounted cash flow  model (SGDCF) , which expresses the relationshi ps 4 
between the key economic levers as follows:  5 
P/B = ROE (1 – b) / (COE – b ROE),  6 
where b is the  plowback ratio , the share of annual profit that is reinvested in the utility to 7 
grow its book equity.27 The product of the plowback ratio and ROE  (b ROE) is the utility’s 8 
growth rate , so as either b or ROE increase s, the growth rate increases as well.  9 
Figure 3 shows how P/B changes as ROE increases  above COE (assumed constant here) , for 10 
different plowback ratios . Increasing plowback ratios,  starting from 0%, are represented by 11 
lines of increasing thickness.  12 
A few things to note. First, for any given plow back ratio, P/B increase s with ROE. This is 13 
just common sense. ROE is profit per dollar of book value; higher profits are more valuable.  14 
Second , for any given ROE, P/B increases with plowback ratio , at an increasingly steeper 15 
rate. A utility’ s value increases non -linearly with growth .28 One important implication is that, 16 
if an investor can buy a utility at a P/B predicated on a certain plowback ratio and growth 17 
rate, it can dramatically increase the value of its investment by increasing the growth rate.  18 
 19

33 Q. Please pause  your explanation  of your analysis . You say MP’s COE is about 6.0%? That 1 
is much lower than their authorized ROE of close to 10%. Please elaborate . 2 
A. My paper for AELP (Exhibit ME -2) discusses this issue in detail. Currently, the cost of equity 3 
for US utilities is on the order of 5% to 6%. Included in the evidence presented in the paper 4 
are professional investment management firms’  estimates of investors’ expected market 5 
returns.  According to GIP owner BlackRock’s most recent forecast (as of September 30, 6 
2024 ), the long -term ( 30-year) expected return, i.e., the cost of equity, for US equities is 7 
7.4%.52 8 
Utilities are lower risk than the market as a whole, so their expected return should be 9 
correspondingly lower. A common model used to estimate the cost of equity is the capital 10 
asset pricing model (CAPM), which expresses the COE as the long -term Treasury expected 11 
return (2.8%) plus a risk -factor, β, multiplied by the difference between the expected returns 12 
on the market as a whole and long -term Treasurys. As of September 30, 2024, the utility β is 13 
0.6, so the utility COE is 3.0% + 0.6 (7. 4% – 3.0%) = 5. 6%.53 14

the provision of equity capital, which is not a natural monopoly, from i ts operating 2 
monopoly, which is , and allow capital providers to compete  to provide equity  directly to the 3

The current approach essentially has investors bid up the price  of the monopoly pocket - 5 
picking machine to a level commensurate with their desired expected return. This is what 6 
equity markets , like that for publicly traded shares,  do. It is also w hat ALLETE has done in 7 
this transaction, potentially yielding a $1.5 -billion unearned windfall . 8

return  at which they’d be willing to provide equity.  I call it “competitive direct equity”  10 
(CDE).  11

distinction between utilities and typical IPOs and VC. In the latter, new investors are willing 17 
to pay more than book value because the new investors believe the existing owners offer a 18 
product or service whose value is determined in a competitive  market  of some sort. The 19 
company could have created a new product for an existing market (e.g., Tesla) or an entirely 20 
new industry (e.g., Uber, OpenAI), expanded supply in an existing market (e.g., new oil   21

A. For utilities, in contrast, the difference between what new investors are willing to pay and 6 
what the existing owners have invested is a reflection solely of a regulatory decision , as 7

rates may be anticipated. ”77 The equity market for utilities is not like the market for the 9

not by any value created by the existing owners in the market of goods and service  through 11 
their ingenuity and risk -taking . 12

rates, as are the salaries of the people developing and implementing new policies.  Cost-of- 17 
service regulation protects utilities from most of the risks faced by companies not subject to 18 
it. To the extent utilities have residual risk, like operational risk, it is reflected in their market - 19 
based cost of capital  and is adequately compensated by the ROR=COC standard . 20

A. The benefit s of competitive direct equity stem primarily from its reduction of investment 3 
risk. The current  utility ownership paradigm  – operating companies owned  by publicly traded 4 
parent companies  – introduces unnecessary and undesirable investment risk into what is 5 
fundamentally a low-risk business.  Figure 7 compares the total return to shareholders (TRS ; 6 
dividends plus capital gains ) to the  realized trailing -twelve -month ROE for the S&P 1500 7 
Utilities Index.  TRS is eight times more volatile than ROE.79 8

and P/B  data. This comparison  likely understates the incremental volatility introduced by the 
publicly traded IOU paradigm. ROE is for the parent companies , not the utility operating 
companies. Parents tend to have more leverage and/or own other businesses with more risk 
than utilities, which would tend to increase the volatility of their ROEs  relative to their utility

Publicly traded parent companies’ additional volatility arises from two causes. First, the 3 
parent does not distribute all of its utility income, but retains some to invest in potential 4 
future growth, which is uncertain. Second, the discounted present value of that future growth 5 
will fluctuate with interest rate and overall market risk appetite.  This incremental risk raises 6

57 investment risk reduction is an incrementally even lower cost of capital than what is reflected 1

level, based on the risk of owning utility equity under the current paradigm of utility 3 
ownership. Competitive direct equity would further reduce ROEs.  4 
Q. Where would the supply of low-cost capital come from?  5 
A. I expect the initial investors would be private equity firms competing for many of the same 6 
assets and opportunities as GIP and CPP – but with an important difference. GIP operates 7 
under  the traditional private equity model : buy a company, grow its earnings, resell  within a 8 
pre-specified holding period,  share in the profits . But not all private equity  is invest ed on 9 
these terms.  10 
Other private equity investors, such as pension s, other retirement asset  managers , and 11 
endowments, have a buy -and-hold approach and look for assets with long -term predictable 12 
yields. Many of these long -term investors also have ESG, climate, energy transition, and 13 
similar mandates  for which utilities are qualifying investments. In principle, utilities are ideal  14 
– the proverbial “widows and orphans” safe and predictable investment. In practice, because 15 
of the volatility introduced by parent company and public market intermediation, these 16 
investors generally do not preferentially invest in utilities.81  17 
 
81 For example, CalPERS ’s ownership of publicly traded utilities is roughly proportional to their

59 Q. Lower ris k directly reduces the cost of equity, which, by drawing in new supplies of 1 
capital, further reduces the cost. Are there o ther benefits?  2 
A. Two other potential CO C-reducing benefit s are these alternative investors’ tax positions and 3 
balance sheets. Investors in public -traded IOU s face double taxation : the corporat ions’ 4 
income tax es and their own dividend taxes.  Direc t invest ment could potentially be structured 5 
to reduce the tax burden , with some of the savings redound ing to consumers in the form of a 6 
lower cost of equity . 7 
BlackRock, Apollo, and other private capital firms invest across the capital structure, debt 8 
and equity. In principle, they could provide the utility both debt and equity at a blended cost 9 
of capital , managing  the capital structure internally . This would only be considered if it were 10 
mutually beneficial  to investors and utility customers , but the potential opportunity merits 11 
investigation.  12 
In addition to these incremental COC -reduction opportunities, there may also be some 13 
broader public interest benefits.  14 
Q. Please elaborate.  15 
A. Two come to mind. First,  to revisit the pool of capital  discussion. While Messrs. Fink and 16 
Rowan’s focus on retirement savings is self -serving, the underlying issue is of genuine public 17 
concern  and national interest . The migration over the last several decades away from defined - 18 
benefit pensions to defined -contribution IRAs and 401(k)s has left many Americans ill - 19 
prepared for retirement. Utilities are one of the few businesses  that provide a long -term 20 
predictable return profile better than bonds – ideal for retirement investors , if they could 21 
invest directly . Utilities  are also substantial, responsible  for hundreds of billions of dollars of 22

A. A second category of public interest benefit s might be referred to as shareholder democracy  4 
or democratic capitalism . Other potential private capital providers include public employee 5 
pension plans. The potential for these plans owning stakes , possibly sufficient to hold board 6

with their local utility due to its excessive profits must pay the  full value of those profits  up- 12 
front to get out from under them . No wonder only 20 utilities have been municipalized since 13 
2000.86 CDE could allow communities to buy  in at book value and build their stake over 14 
time.87 15

61 Q. A key democratic capitalism benefit of publicly traded utilities is that they are  1 
accessible to individuals. Can CDE provide similar opportunities for individual 2 
investors?  3 
A. I expect CDE, once implemented, to quickly generate  compelling investment opportunities 4 
for individuals, comparable in liquidity and transaction cost to publicly traded equities, but 5 
with a more attractive risk -reward profile than products currently available.  6 
One of the most successful financial innovations  of the last half -century  is the exchange 7 
traded fund (ETF) , which assemble s a portfolio of assets  for sale to individual investors on 8 
public stock exchanges.  Because they are traded on exchanges, they are liquid and have low 9 
transaction costs . ETF management fees also are low, because several firms compete to 10 
provide them, including Vanguard, State Street, Invesco, Charles Schwab, and the largest, 11 
BlackRock’s iShares .88 I envision ETF providers assembling portfolios of utility CDE stakes  12 
for sale to individual investors.  13 
Such ETFs might offer a unique ly attractive risk -reward profile. For example, if the utility 14 
distributes 100%  of CDE income and the CDE R OE is periodically reset to the prevailing 15 
COE, the market value of the  CDE stake should be relatively constant over time, with a 16 
return inversely correlated with overall market risk appetite (or aversion) .89  17 
These are just a few examples of the types of democratic capitalism opportunities CDE might 18 
engender.  All would require further investigation , development , and public deliberation . I  19

3. The Commission Can and Should Start  Straightaway.  3 
Q. At what point in the regulatory process would this take place?  4 
A. For MP, t he current sale to GIP/CPP should be aborted, for the numerous reasons I’ve 5 
explained. But the proposed sale of MP presents a unique opportunity to pilot CDE.  ALLETE 6 
and MP have laid much of the dealmaking groundwork – engaging lawyers, investment 7 
bankers, and other advisors; filling data rooms; and assembling transaction teams. These 8 
efforts could lar gely be repurposed to a CDE process. Certainly, much additional work 9 
remains, but the Commission should not allow ALLETE and MP’s efforts to date to go to 10 
waste.  11 
More  generally, the natural time for a utility to “go to market” for CDE would be toward the 12 
end of a rate case, once the utility and regulator have agreed on a capex forecast . Instead of 13 
defaulting to the utility or its parent providing all incremental equity needs (through retained 14 
earnings and/or additional equity), the utility would  solicit offers from multiple parties who 15 
compete on the basis of offered ROE. The ROE that clears this market process is, by 16 
definition, the market -based COE.  17 
Q. Would this process apply to the equity already invested in the utility?  18 
A. Numerous CDE implementation details remain to be identified, explored, and resolved. I 19 
expect this would be among the most contentious.  A case could be made that the ROE that 20 
clears the market for incremental equity reflects the market price and should apply to all 21

A. The next step would be to commission a study , convene  a technical  conference, and/ or open a 4

technological, etc. – that would need to be investigated and addressed in implementing such a 6

solution , are common across all states ; and (2) investors and regulators share a common 9 
interest in standardized processes and investment terms across utilities and states  to facilitate 10 
the maximum participation  and efficiency.90 11 
V. CONCLUSION  12 
Q. Do you have any concluding comments?  13 
This transaction casts a spotlight on two critical, interconnected issues facing the 14 
Commission, MP, and MP customers: the cost of meeting the CES, and the perverse 15 
incentives created by excessive authorized ROEs. Excessive ROEs exacerbate CES cost 16 
concerns in two ways: they make the customer cost of all capital spending approximately 17 
40% higher than it should be; and they create powerful incentives for MP to maximize its 18 
capital spending because that excess 40% redounds directly to MP’s owners. These higher 19
